turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Greek diacritics.
turn.1: what are the different modes of articulation in greece
turn.2: The diaeresis can be combined with the acute, grave and circumflex but never with breathings, since the letter with the diaeresis cannot be the first vowel of the word.
turn.3: what is the function of the diaeresis
turn.4: In Modern Greek, the combination of the acute and diaeresis indicates a stressed vowel after a hiatus.
turn.6: In textbooks and dictionaries of Ancient Greek, the macron—"—and breve—"—are often used over , , and to indicate that they are long or short, respectively.
turn.8: In some modern non-standard orthographies of Greek dialects, such as Cypriot Greek and Griko, a caron (ˇ) may be used on some consonants to show a palatalized pronunciation.
turn.10: They are not encoded as precombined characters in Unicode, so they are typed by adding the to the Greek letter.
turn.11: what are the different modes of articulation in greece
turn.12: Latin diacritics on Greek letters may not be supported by many fonts, and as a fall-back a caron may be replaced by an iota ⟨ι⟩ following the consonant.
